newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia likely to reverse mining proposal - paper.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia likely to reverse mining proposal - paper.

text.p: The Indonesian mines and energy ministry is likely to reverse a proposal which requires foreign mining companies to allocate the government a 10 percent stake in future projects, Neraca newspaper reported on Saturday.
The paper quoted Adjat Sudradjat, director-general of mining, as saying on Friday that the proposal was not compulsory.
"If we follow what has been said by (State Secretary) Murdiono, there is a possibility that the proposal will not be continued," Sudradjat was quoted saying.
State Secretary Murdiono told reporters on Thursday the government would be consistent with its policy that allowed 100 percent foreign-owned companies to operate in the country.O
Officials at the ministry were not available for comment.
"The proposal is not yet included in the draft of the seventh generation contract of work," Sudradjat said.
"It is not true. Our position now is that we are about to enter negotiation," he said.
"It is impossible for us to drastically change the principles of contracts of work before both parties agree (contractor and government)," he said.
Investment Minister Sanyoto Sastrowardoyo said he was not aware of the reasons or motivation behind the proposals.
Under the proposed changes for the minerals mining sector, foreign companies are required to allocate at least a 10 percent stake in future ventures to the government for free.

The companies would also be required to share capital gains made in stock exchanges outside Indonesia with their shareholders, and the raising of additional capital through a public offering of shares must be done in Indonesia.
The government informed mining companies on Thursday that similar changes would be made to the coal sector.
A copy of the proposed changes obtained by Reuters showed that coal companies had to divest 51 percent of their equity in projects to Indonesians by the 10th year of operation.
